data.title: BBC weather forecast: Sweltering HEATWAVE continues this week
data.meta_description: BRITAIN is to reach record-breaking temperatures this week as the heatwave continues across the country with most places likely to top 30 degrees Celsius in the next seven days.
data.text:
BBC weather: Highs of 30C set to sweep south-east England

UK weather is showing no signs of cooling down as forecaster Carol Kirkwood told BBC Breakfast viewers temperatures will continue to skyrocket this week.

She said: “It is going to be a hot one, in fact the temperature at the moment in the Isle of Wight is 21.8 degrees Celsius and here in London it’s 18.6.”

Yesterday the temperatures went back up to 32 degrees Celsius after a weekend of thunderstorms and heavy rain in some places.

Today there is a chance a few areas in the south coast and far south west could be hit with one of two showers.

However, forecasters expect most of the downpours to remain in the English Channel or close to the near continent.

Cloud is possible in south east Scotland, where it could also feel cooler in the afternoon.

But again temperatures are likely to hit 31 or 32 degrees Celsius in England and Wales and mostly sunny in southern counties as showers move away.

There will be a bit of cloud across north sea coasts this evening, but temperatures still on the high side; perhaps humid in southern parts of England and Wales.

Not a lot of rain in the forecast this week, instead sunny and bright for most with the small chance of outbreaks in the far south west on Tuesday.

Temperatures are to rise in Scotland and Northern Ireland tomorrow, where figures could at worst be in the mid 20s.

Meanwhile, 30 degrees or higher across inland parts of England and Wales also largely dry with lengthy spells of sunshine.

Light winds on Wednesday mean more sunshine around, but cloudy across the east coast in places such as Edinburgh, Newcastle and Hull.

There will be little or no showers in the south west and temperatures remaining in the mid to high 20s on Wednesday afternoon.

On Thursday a cold weather front will loom to the north of Scotland which will drag in a bit more cloud across Northern Ireland and Scotland.

Risk of showers in the Grampians, but dry further south where temperatures could peak close to 30 degrees Celsius.

Invalid email

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

The threat of heavy downpours will remain on Friday, although it will still be a pleasant day for most Britons.

With hot conditions remaining across the country, bookmaker Coral has made it 1/4 this summer will be the hottest ever recorded.

Coral spokesperson, John Hill said: “The nation continues to sizzle and with temperatures likely to rise even further over the next couple of weeks, the odds have been slashed on this summer ending as the hottest on record in the UK.

“There has been a hosepipe ban enforced in parts of the UK and the betting suggests the whole of the nation could be hit with the ban by the time the summer is up.”

BBC Breakfast airs weekdays on BBC One at 6am.
